paper_metadata.title: Genomic Screening Identifies Individuals at High Risk for Hereditary Transthyretin Amyloidosis
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the TTR V142I variant, including penetrance data and individual case details.

patients.demographics: Median age 57 years, 81% female, 53% African American, 47% Hispanic/Latinx
patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR) related systemic features

individual_records.phenotype_details: Heart failure, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis
individual_records.evidence_sentence: At the time of result disclosure, 18 (56%) participants had at least one hATTR-related systemic feature.
This was largely driven by the high prevalence of CTS (N = 10, 31%) and SS (N = 10, 31%).
This was largely driven by the high prevalence of CTS (N = 10, 31%) and SS (N = 10, 31%).
None had a previous diagnosis of hATTR.

functional_data.summary: The TTR V142I variant is associated with increased risk for cardiac amyloidosis.

variants.population_frequency: Up to 4% in African Americans, 1% in Hispanic/Latinx populations.
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on clinical features and population studies.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of genomic screening in identifying at-risk individuals.
key_quotes: The majority of V142I-positive individuals had hATTR-related systemic features at the time of result disclosure.
Genomic screening can help identify hATTR risk and guide management early on.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text.
